verses.text: Now concerning food offered to idols: we know that we all have knowledge. Knowledge puffs up, but love builds up.
verses.comment: Paul begins by addressing a practical question but shifts quickly to a deeper spiritual truth, warning against pride gained from knowledge. Note how love is placed as superior to mere knowledge, foreshadowing the primacy of charity over intellect as central to Christian living (cf. 1 Cor. 13:2).

verses.text: If anyone imagines that he knows something, he does not yet know as he ought to know.
verses.comment: True wisdom is humility and recognizing our limits before God. Paul subtly teaches that knowledge must be complete and rightly ordered – only in humility do we truly understand (cf. Prov. 3:7).

verses.text: But if anyone loves God, he is known by God.
verses.comment: Paul shifts from human knowledge to divine knowledge. The highest goal is not what we know, but being known and loved by God, which is central in biblical spirituality (cf. John 10:14).

verses.text: So, as to eating food offered to idols, we know that ‘an idol is nothing in the world,’ and that ‘there is no God but one.’
verses.comment: Paul affirms monotheism and the powerlessness of idols, reflecting the Shema (Deut. 6:4), the central creed. The unity of God is foundational for the faith community.

verses.text: For even if there are so-called gods, whether in heaven or on earth—as indeed there are many ‘gods’ and many ‘lords’—
verses.comment: Paul acknowledges that others believe in many spiritual powers, but stresses their falsehood and impotence compared to the one true Lord. This prepares for the confession of faith in the next verse.

verses.text: Yet for us there is one God, the Father, from whom all things came and for whom we exist, and one Lord, Jesus Christ, through whom all things came and through whom we exist.
verses.comment: Here is a high Christological statement: Jesus Christ is presented as the divine agent of creation, co-equal with the Father (cf. John 1:3). This passage is used by the historical Church to support belief in Christ's divinity and the procession of all things from the Father through the Son.

verses.text: However, not everyone possesses this knowledge. Some, because of former association with idols, eat food as really offered to an idol, and their conscience, being weak, is defiled.
verses.comment: Paul begins to introduce the principle of considering the weak in faith. Spiritual maturity means not causing harm to the conscience of others, a foundational principle for responsible Christian action (cf. Rom. 14:23).

verses.text: Food does not bring us closer to God. We are no worse off if we do not eat, and no better if we do.
verses.comment: Paul clarifies that rituals or dietary rules alone do not make one righteous before God. True holiness is deeper than outward practices (cf. Rom. 14:17).

verses.text: But take care that this right of yours does not somehow become a stumbling block to the weak.
verses.comment: Paul stresses charity and personal restraint for the sake of others' spiritual health, introducing a principle of self-sacrifice for the good of the community, a mark of mature Christian discipleship (cf. Matt. 18:6).

verses.text: For if anyone sees you who have knowledge eating in an idol’s temple, will he not be encouraged, if his conscience is weak, to eat food offered to idols?
verses.comment: Knowledge can lead others astray if used without love. Here, Paul again prioritizes the spiritual well-being of others over exercising personal freedoms.

verses.text: And by your knowledge this weak person is destroyed, the brother for whom Christ died.
verses.comment: Christ's sacrifice is universal and personal—every believer is precious. Paul reminds the Church that unity and love for one another reflect Christ’s own love, which is shown perfectly through sacrifice.

verses.text: Thus, sinning against your brothers and wounding their conscience when it is weak, you sin against Christ.
verses.comment: To harm a fellow Christian is to harm Christ Himself (cf. Matt. 25:40; Acts 9:4), revealing the depth of the unity of believers in Christ's body. This echoes the spiritual reality of communion among all faithful.

verses.text: Therefore, if food causes my brother to fall, I will never eat meat again, so that I might not cause my brother to stumble.
verses.comment: Paul concludes by choosing personal sacrifice for the sake of others, modeling mature Christian love—echoing Christ's own self-giving love. Living this way is essential for true unity in the Church and for becoming a sign of Christ’s sacrificial love for the world.
